patient_information: Age: 26 years Sex: female Travel history: recent trip to Ghana
chief_complaint: Localized swelling on the left leg for approximately three weeks
history_of_present_illness: The swelling has developed slowly over the past 3 weeks. It is itchy, but not painful. There is no history of fever; no history of arthropod bites.
exposure_and_epidemiology: Travel details: 6-week trip to Ghana Vector exposures: No mosquito or tick exposure reported
physical_exam: Lesion description: Localized swelling with a central scab, slightly hyperaemic skin surrounding the swelling Lymphadenopathy: No lymphadenopathy present Other findings: Patient is afibrile while the rest of the physical examination is normal
differential_diagnosis: Most important diagnoses: ["Cutaneous myiasis (Tumbu fly)", "Localized bacterial skin and soft-tissue infections", "Spider bite with eschar-like central necrosis"] Reasoning: The slow growth of the lesion over several weeks, absence of lymphadenopathy and systemic symptoms, and the localized itchy nature make myiasis the most likely differential diagnosis.
management_and_clinical_course: Treatment: ["Gently remove scab", "Apply white petroleum jelly or liquid paraffin to block larval respiratory spiracles"] Outcome: The lesion was covered with white petroleum jelly and superinfected. The patient returned 2 days later for review.
final_diagnosis: Diagnosis: Cutaneous myiasis (Tumbu fly) Confirmation method: Larva easily removed with forceps Evidence: The slow growth of the lesion, absence of lymphadenopathy and systemic symptoms, and the localized itchy nature make this diagnosis likely.
